author: Caleb Taylor
title: King Charles reportedly gives Australia tour green light amid positive cancer treatment
text:
King Charles has reportedly given royal aides the green light to prepare for a tour of Australia.
This comes as his
cancer treatment appears to be having positive effects, two months after he publicly confirmed his diagnosis after undergoing treatment for an enlarged prostate.

The King, 75, and his wife
Queen Camilla, 76, are set to return to Australian shores in October.
“The King is raring to go and keen to get on with the job,” a palace source told
The Sun.
The source reported the King is “over the moon” with how his treatment is progressing, prompting the King’s team to “supercharge” the Australia plans.
“He knows he can’t hang around and is feeling extremely positive after tests meant he could attend the
Easter Sunday service and spend time meeting the public, which he has missed,” the source said.
“Although his doctors are keeping an eye on his
health, he’s itching to take the reins and get back to his public role as head of state.
“He wants to follow his mother Queen Elizabeth II’s mantra, that he needs to be seen to be believed.”
The King and Queen are set to embark on a two-week trip across Australia, New Zealand and Samoa.
However, the insider reports the itinerary will be stripped back to allow for more downtime, ensuring the King has enough recovery between commitments.
It was announced in February that the King has been receiving treatment for cancer after undergoing a corrective procedure for an enlarged prostate.
While he kept a low profile following the news, Charles and Camilla made a significant public appearance at an
Easter Service last weekend, shaking hands and speaking with onlookers.
The milestone was a major positive sign of his recovery.
The King’s most recent visit to Australia was as the Prince of Wales in 2018, for the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane.
He has previously made the trip to Australia at least 15 times, with official visits to every state and territory, as well as attending Geelong Grammar School’s Timbertop campus as a student in 1966.
It is believed Charles’ visit could coincide with the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting to be held in Samoa in October.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese released a statement on March 4 about preparations for King Charles to tour Down Under.
“The King has shown his compassion for Australians affected by recent natural disasters, just as Australians have shown compassion and support for the King following his cancer diagnosis,” he said.
“The King, Queen, and members of the royal family are always welcome in Australia.”
The late
Queen Elizabeth II last came to Australia in 2011, visiting Perth, Melbourne, Brisbane, Canberra.
Elizabeth, who died in 2022, currently remains the only serving monarch to have made the trip to Australia — visiting 16 times throughout her reign.
